content:
I am trying to read a rather impenetrable paper (here) that calls "interface" of a functor MMM with small domain C and complete codomain D the following construction.
image.png
If this construction makes sense, there is certainly a way to express it in terms of a universal construction; one would be tempted to write that (in this horrible notation) IntM:c↦∫xMxC(x,c)Int_M : c \mapsto \int_x Mx^{C(x,c)}IntM​:c↦∫x​MxC(x,c); so the interface of MMM is the limit of M weighted by y(c)y(c)y(c): too bad that the integration variable xxx is now covariant in both positions, so the end doesn't really make sense.

This seems like a general trick to change the variance of a functor; note that instead, by the usual Togakure-ryū trick, ∫xMxC(−,x)≅M\int_x Mx^{C(-,x)} \cong M∫x​MxC(−,x)≅M. Can it be the case that what I'm using as the weight is the contravariant yoneda embedding y˙:C→[C,Set]op\dot y : C \to [C,Set]^{op}y˙​:C→[C,Set]op, so the limit of MMM (covariant) weighted by y˙\dot yy˙​ yields the functor in question?

It seems like it's c↦limC/c→πCC→MDc \mapsto \mathop{\mathrm{lim}} \mathcal C/c \xrightarrow{\pi_\mathcal{C}} \mathcal C \xrightarrow{M} \mathcal Dc↦limC/cπC​​CM​D if it's the way it's written; it seems like it's using the fact that the codomain fibration is a fibration, and hence gives rise to an indexed category, not just a coindexed category. Of course this actually only works if C\mathcal CC has pullbacks. No idea why it's called an "interface".

it seems like it's using the fact that the codomain fibration is a fibration

I don't think any additional assumption is needed for the construction to make sense; the problem is: what is it, really? It's clearly some sort of weighted limit, but a trick is needed to circumvent the covariance problem.
I believe my suspicion is correct: the diagram is M, the weight is in fact a family of weights, C→[C,Set]oC \to [C,Set]^oC→[C,Set]o

thus the result is not a single object of D, but an entire functor C to D, contravariant because of how I chose coYoneda as "system of weights"; a similar (dual) trick is in Street-Walters Yoneda structures, defining the weighted colimit w⊗fw\otimes fw⊗f :

image.png

where (in Cat) the weight is a functor X→[Yo,Set]X \to [Y^o,Set]X→[Yo,Set]

well, I don't want to outsource the grunt work on you to check that this indeed is the construction at hand; instead... what intuition is there behind this construction? Have you seen instances of it "in nature"? It's the first time I see this

Just noting that the poset case seems like quite a simple thing: given an order-preserving map f:P→Qf: P \to Qf:P→Q where QQQ has all meets, the interface of fff is the order-reversing map sending xxx to ⋀y≤xf(y)\bigwedge_{y \leq x} f(y)⋀y≤x​f(y).

If PPP is something like an "information order", domain-theory style, then it would seem to me like, as we gain more information, we "see" more and more of QQQ through fff, and then we need to cast a wider and wider "net" (=the limit cone) to capture the whole image of fff.
The net being wider and wider corresponds to the tip of the cone regressing further and further back.

Perhaps this is also the intuition that the word "interface" is trying to convey: if there is some notion of direction in the domain of MMM---perhaps it is a poset, or a directed category---so that it makes sense to look at how the image of MMM grows along the direction, then the limit indexed by ccc is a way of "packaging" the "image of MMM up to object ccc" into a single object (from which it can be accessed through the cone projections), and so acts as a single-entry interface with that whole image?

I think it's something like that, just the limit projections are indexed over pairs of the form (x,u:x→c)(x, u : x\to c)(x,u:x→c), so that you project onto the function Mu:Mx→McMu : Mx \to McMu:Mx→Mc, instead of just "M at level c"
("function", if M has codomain Set)
Say M:ω→SetM : \omega \to SetM:ω→Set is a chain of sets. Clearly, the category ω/[n]\omega/[n]ω/[n] is just the total order {0<1<⋯<n}\{0<1<\dots<n\}{0<1<⋯<n}.

Hence the projection πn\pi_nπn​ is just the inclusion, and the limit of [n]↪ω→Set[n] \hookrightarrow \omega \to Set[n]↪ω→Set is... M0M_0M0​ for every n (the domain of the diagram has an initial object).

Here's a more fun example, maybe. Let XXX be a topological space, let PPP be a presheaf on XXX, and let U\mathcal{U}U be a filtered open cover of XXX (seen as a subposet of the lattice of opens of XXX).

Then, restricting PPP to the opens in U\mathcal{U}U, we have a functor PU:Uop→SetP_{\mathcal{U}}: \mathcal{U}^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{Set}PU​:Uop→Set.
The interface of this functor is the functor IntPU:U→Set\mathrm{Int}_{P_\mathcal{U}}: \mathcal{U} \to \mathrm{Set}IntPU​​:U→Set which sends an open U∈UU \in \mathcal{U}U∈U to limU⊆V∈UPV\mathrm{lim}_{U \subseteq V \in \mathcal{U}} PVlimU⊆V∈U​PV.

Assuming wlog that U\mathcal{U}U contains ∅\emptyset∅, we have that IntPU∅\mathrm{Int}_{P_\mathcal{U}} \emptysetIntPU​​∅ is exactly the set of "compatible families" which show up in the sheaf condition for PPP with respect to U\mathcal{U}U. The general IntPUU\mathrm{Int}_{P_\mathcal{U}} UIntPU​​U seem to be something like "compatible families relative to UUU" in the sense that we are only allowed to look at the image of PPP on opens in U\mathcal{U}U that contain UUU.

After some more discussion and thinking, it seems that this construction is able to generate some trivial examples, and some interesting ones:

  • If M:ω→SetM : \omega \to SetM:ω→Set is a chain, IntMInt_MIntM​ is the functor constant at M0M0M0, and if M:ωo→SetM : \omega^o \to SetM:ωo→Set is an antichain, IntMInt_MIntM​ is the functor constant at lim⁡M\lim MlimM (all unbounded subposets {n≥n+1≥… }\{n\ge n+1\ge \dots \}{n≥n+1≥…} of ωo\omega^oωo are cofinal.
  • If M:O(X)o→SetM : O(X)^o \to SetM:O(X)o→Set is a presheaf, there is an associated copresheaf sending UUU to lim⁡V⊇UMV\lim_{V\supseteq U} MVlimV⊇U​MV, which looks like a "costalk" (?)
  • If M:BA→SetM : BA \to SetM:BA→Set is the (left) action of a monoid AAA on a set XXX, there is an associated right action on the same set, and this correspondence exchanges the left regular representation of A on itself, with the right regular representation.

Especially the last item of the list feels Isbell-y (Isbell duality behaves like that on the regular representations of the monoid A), which is the initial suspicion I had reading the definition...

The second example is also constant at MXMXMX if applied to the "whole" presheaf since O(X)O(X)O(X) has a greatest element, that's why I suggested relativising to a filtered cover, where it does seem to become more interesting.
Oh when D is Set is this one of the functors in the Isbell adjunction?

I am still struggling to understand what is the universal property of this object; sending MMM to IntMInt_MIntM​ is certainly a covariant functor [C,D]→[Co,D][C,D] \to [C^o,D][C,D]→[Co,D]. Yet, look what happens when I try to check whether it is a right adjoint "for formal reasons". IntM(c)=∫xMxhom⁡(x,c)Int_M(c) = \int_x Mx^{\hom(x,c)}IntM​(c)=∫x​Mxhom(x,c) (this is the only variance that makes IntMInt_MIntM​ contravariant in ccc,a s it is defined to be).
image.png
which is... weird, and certainly wrong; but where is the mistake?

It also seems like "Int" is an idempotent construction:

IntM(IntM(c))=∫xhom⁡(x,c)⋔IntM(x)=∫xhom⁡(x,c)⋔(∫yhom⁡(y,x)⋔My)=∫xyhom⁡(x,c)⋔(hom⁡(y,x)⋔My)=∫xy(hom⁡(x,c)×hom⁡(y,x))⋔My=∫y(∫xhom⁡(x,c)×hom⁡(y,x))⋔My=∫yhom⁡(y,c)⋔My=IntM(c)\begin{array}{rcl}Int_M(Int_M(c)) &=& \displaystyle \int_x \hom(x,c)\pitchfork Int_M(x)\\&=& \displaystyle \int_x \hom(x,c)\pitchfork \Big(\int_y\hom(y,x)\pitchfork My\Big)\\&=& \displaystyle \int_{xy} \hom(x,c)\pitchfork (\hom(y,x)\pitchfork My)\\&=& \displaystyle \int_{xy} (\hom(x,c)\times \hom(y,x))\pitchfork My\\&=& \displaystyle \int_{y} \Big(\int^x\hom(x,c)\times \hom(y,x)\Big)\pitchfork My\\&=& \displaystyle \int_{y} \hom(y,c)\pitchfork My\\&=& Int_M(c)\end{array}IntM​(IntM​(c))​=======​∫x​hom(x,c)⋔IntM​(x)∫x​hom(x,c)⋔(∫y​hom(y,x)⋔My)∫xy​hom(x,c)⋔(hom(y,x)⋔My)∫xy​(hom(x,c)×hom(y,x))⋔My∫y​(∫xhom(x,c)×hom(y,x))⋔My∫y​hom(y,c)⋔MyIntM​(c)​
Furthermore, there is a universal dinatural copointing IntM⇒..MInt_M \overset{..}\Rightarrow MIntM​⇒..M given on components by πc,idc\pi_{c,\text{id}_c}πc,idc​​...
I am not particularly happy to have discovered an example of idempotent contracomonad...
In MxC(x,c)Mx^{C(x, c)}MxC(x,c), xxx is covariant in both positions, so that's not a well-defined end...

I know, at the same time the definition as lim⁡(Elts(hom⁡(−,c))→C→MD)\lim(Elts(\hom(-,c)) \to C \overset M\to D)lim(Elts(hom(−,c))→C→MD) plus the fact that the latter is the limit of MMM weighted by hom⁡(−,c)\hom(-,c)hom(−,c), say that something like that should be true. Again, that's the only variance that makes the result contravariant in c; ∫xMxhom⁡(c,x)\int_x Mx^{\hom(c,x)}∫x​Mxhom(c,x) makes sense, but it's just McMcMc.

Together with @Emily (she/her) I developed a language that accounts for the fact that these situations exist "in nature", but I would like to be sure there isn't an easier explanation for this construction, before I resort to "(2,0)-ends"...

Just a simple example to show that the interface is not "idempotent" in any meaningful way: let PPP be the poset x,y<⊤x, y < \topx,y<⊤ and QQQ be the poset ⊥<x,y<⊤\bot < x, y < \top⊥<x,y<⊤, and let j:P→Qj: P \to Qj:P→Q be the obvious inclusion.

Then

  • Intj:Pop→Q\mathrm{Int} j: P^\mathrm{op} \to QIntj:Pop→Q is defined by x↦xx \mapsto xx↦x, y↦yy \mapsto yy↦y, and ⊤↦⊥\top \mapsto \bot⊤↦⊥, while
  • Int(Intj):P→Q\mathrm{Int}(\mathrm{Int} j): P \to QInt(Intj):P→Q is constant at ⊥\bot⊥.

This reminded me of something that I worked out a few years ago, and indeed I think it's an instance of it.

Suppose we are given an indexed category S:C→Cat\mathcal{S}: C \to \mathrm{Cat}S:C→Cat.
Then, there are

  1. a category OplaxConeS\mathrm{OplaxCone}_\mathcal{S}OplaxConeS​ of oplax cones under S\mathcal{S}S, which are pairs of a category DDD and an oplax natural transformation FFF from S\mathcal{S}S to the constant DDD --- a component of this at ccc is a functor Fc:Sc→DFc: \mathcal{S}c \to DFc:Sc→D;
  2. a functor ConeS:Cop×OplaxConeS→Cat\mathsf{Cone}_\mathcal{S}: C^\mathrm{op} \times \mathrm{OplaxCone}_\mathcal{S} \to \mathrm{Cat}ConeS​:Cop×OplaxConeS​→Cat which, on objects, is defined by sending (c,D,F)(c, D, F)(c,D,F) to the category of cones in DDD over Fc:Sc→DFc: \mathcal{S}c \to DFc:Sc→D.

Moreover, if DDD is complete, this functor is naturally isomorphic to a functor LimS\mathsf{Lim}_\mathcal{S}LimS​ which sends (c,D,F)(c, D, F)(c,D,F) to the slice D/limFcD/{\mathrm{lim} Fc}D/limFc...

So in particular if we fix a oplax cone (D,F)(D, F)(D,F) under S\mathcal{S}S, this gives us a functor Cop→CatC^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{Cat}Cop→Cat; actually two equivalent descriptions of it, when DDD is complete.

I think we can see this "interface" as arising from

  • choosing S ⁣:C→Cat\mathcal{S}\colon C \to \mathrm{Cat}S:C→Cat to be c↦C/cc \mapsto C/cc↦C/c,
  • choosing the oplax cone under S\mathcal{S}S to have components F∘domc ⁣:C/c→DF \circ \mathrm{dom}_c\colon C/c \to DF∘domc​:C/c→D (this is actually a "strict" cone, both lax and oplax)

Then even without any condition on DDD we get a contravariant functor Cop→CatC^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{Cat}Cop→Cat, sending ccc to the category of cones in DDD over F∘domcF \circ \mathrm{dom}_cF∘domc​; when DDD is complete, this functor becomes "representable" as c↦D/IntFcc \mapsto D/\mathrm{Int} Fcc↦D/IntFc

It is interesting that the Yoneda lemma can be recovered as a very special case of the natural isomorphism between ConeS\mathsf{Cone}_\mathcal{S}ConeS​ and LimS\mathsf{Lim}_\mathcal{S}LimS​ when S:Cop→Cat\mathcal{S}: C^\mathrm{op} \to \mathrm{Cat}S:Cop→Cat is the contravariant slice functor, c↦c/Cc \mapsto c/Cc↦c/C.

In any case, I think the fundamental duality at play here, independent of any conditions on DDD, is the one that given a covariantly CCC-indexed category & an oplax cone under it, produces a contravariantly CCC-indexed category.
Somehow the oplax cone acts as a dualiser...

I had not tried to work out the functoriality of OplaxCone\mathrm{OplaxCone}OplaxCone, but presumably there is some sort of fibration

∫OplaxConeC→[C,Cat]\int \mathrm{OplaxCone}^C \to [C, \mathrm{Cat}]∫OplaxConeC→[C,Cat]

where the objects of the "Grothendieck construction" above are pairs of S:C→Cat\mathcal{S}: C \to \mathrm{Cat}S:C→Cat and an oplax cone under S\mathcal{S}S; then Cone\mathsf{Cone}Cone could assemble into a functor ∫OplaxConeC→[Cop,Cat]\int \mathrm{OplaxCone}^C \to [C^\mathrm{op}, \mathrm{Cat}]∫OplaxConeC→[Cop,Cat], and the whole duality would then be a span between [C,Cat][C, \mathrm{Cat}][C,Cat] and [Cop,Cat][C^\mathrm{op}, \mathrm{Cat}][Cop,Cat] with tip ∫OplaxConeC\int \mathrm{OplaxCone}^C∫OplaxConeC...
I agree that whatever is going on here is formal; hence my obsession!

I think my last message works if [C,Cat][C, \mathrm{Cat}][C,Cat] and [Cop,Cat][C^\mathrm{op}, \mathrm{Cat}][Cop,Cat] are categories of functors and oplax natural transformations, and the tip of the span is an (oplax, again?) comma category of [C,Cat][C, \mathrm{Cat}][C,Cat] over the functor Cat→[C,Cat]\mathrm{Cat} \to [C, \mathrm{Cat}]Cat→[C,Cat] which sends DDD to the constant at DDD...
Of course the projection from the comma should be some sort of fibration, but I don't know if the other leg valued in [Cop,Cat][C^\mathrm{op}, \mathrm{Cat}][Cop,Cat] has some nice properties

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

In MxC(x,c)Mx^{C(x, c)}MxC(x,c), xxx is covariant in both positions, so that's not a well-defined end...

This should still work as an end though right? You have a functor C×Cop×C→DC \times C^{op} \times C \to DC×Cop×C→D sending (x,c,y)↦MyC(x,c)(x, c, y) \mapsto My^{C(x, c)}(x,c,y)↦MyC(x,c). So if you hold ccc fixed, this gets you a functor C×C↦DC \times C \mapsto DC×C↦D sending (x,y)↦MyC(x,c)(x, y) \mapsto My^{C(x, c)}(x,y)↦MyC(x,c). Precomposing with the diagonal C→C×CC \to C \times CC→C×C gets you a functor C→DC \to DC→D sending x↦MxC(x,c)x \mapsto Mx^{C(x, c)}x↦MxC(x,c). Then you can take the end over this by precomposing with the projection Cop×C→CC^\text{op} \times C \to CCop×C→C, no?

I guess this is just the general phenomenon of expressing the limit of a functor H:C→DH : C \to DH:C→D as ∫cH(c)\int_c H(c)∫c​H(c), by first precomposing with the projection Cop×C→CC^{op} \times C \to CCop×C→C.

Ruby Khondaker (she/her) said:

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

In MxC(x,c)Mx^{C(x, c)}MxC(x,c), xxx is covariant in both positions, so that's not a well-defined end...

This should still work as an end though right? You have a functor C×Cop×C→DC \times C^{op} \times C \to DC×Cop×C→D sending (x,c,y)↦MyC(x,c)(x, c, y) \mapsto My^{C(x, c)}(x,c,y)↦MyC(x,c). So if you hold ccc fixed, this gets you a functor C×C↦DC \times C \mapsto DC×C↦D sending (x,y)↦MyC(x,c)(x, y) \mapsto My^{C(x, c)}(x,y)↦MyC(x,c). Precomposing with the diagonal C→C×CC \to C \times CC→C×C gets you a functor C→DC \to DC→D sending x↦MxC(x,c)x \mapsto Mx^{C(x, c)}x↦MxC(x,c). Then you can take the end over this by precomposing with the projection Cop×C→CC^\text{op} \times C \to CCop×C→C, no?

I guess this is just the general phenomenon of expressing the limit of a functor H:C→DH : C \to DH:C→D as ∫cH(c)\int_c H(c)∫c​H(c), by first precomposing with the projection Cop×C→CC^{op} \times C \to CCop×C→C. Perhaps I misunderstood what you meant when you said "not well-defined"?

What you are describing is a "(0,2)-end" in the language of https://arxiv.org/abs/2011.13881

Oh cool! I had no idea there was a name for these sorts of things. Though, since we take two covariant arguments, would that be a (0,2)(0, 2)(0,2)-end in the language of that paper?
image.png

I suppose what I outlined in the second paragraph illustrates that (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1)-ends are equivalent to limits.
yeah, sorry I meant (0,2) :-)
